STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 1, 2021
Kevin Mitchell
Washtenaw County Youth Center
4125 Washtenaw Avenue
Ann Arbor, MI 48104
RE: License #: CE810254752
Washtenaw County Youth Center
4125 Washtenaw Avenue
Ann Arbor, MI 48104
Dear Mr. Mitchell:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
06/09/21. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, note why the previous plan failed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Kari Muntean, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 395-0920
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
(e) One of four new employee files reviewed contained two references that were
completed over a year prior.
(i) Four of seven employee files were not compliant with the rule. Two of four new
employee files contained central registry clearances where one was done more than
30 days prior to hire, and the other was done after hire. Two of three existing
employee files contained central registry clearances done three days over one year.
REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 04/15/2020 and CAP, 04/24/20. The
facility must identify why the previous plan failed and how they are going to
ensure compliance.
R 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical examinations.
(1) An initial health screening shall be completed for each
resident within 24 hours of admission to a facility.
1

One of three current resident files reviewed did not contain an initial health
screening. The facility is also reminded to document if there is any reason in a delay
of this, such as a youth refusing an exam.
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's case record:
(a) Name, address, birth date, sex, gender, race, height,
weight, hair color, eye color, identifying marks, religious
preference, and school status.
(c) A brief description of the resident's preparation for
placement and general physical and emotional state at the time
of admission.
(a) One of three current resident files reviewed left religion blank on the initial
documentation.
(c) One of three current resident files reviewed did not document the resident’s
preparation for placement at the time of placement.
R 400.4153 Shelter care and detention institutions; preliminary service
plans.
Within 7 calendar days of admission, a plan shall be developed
for each resident. The plan shall include all of the following:
(a) The reason for care.
(b) An assessment of the resident’s immediate and specific
needs.
(c) The specific services to be provided by the institution.
(d) Other resources to meet the resident’s needs.
Two of three current resident files reviewed contained preliminary service plans that
were completed one day late.
R 400.4154 Shelter care and detention institutions; service plans.
(1) Within 30 calendar days after admission and every 15
calendar days thereafter, an institution shall complete a written
service plan. The service plan shall include all of the following:
(a) The reason for continued care.
(b) Evaluation of service needs.
(c) Ongoing service needs.
(d) How service needs will be met.
2

(e) Unmet service needs and the reasons those needs are
unmet.
One applicable current resident file contained a late 30-day service plan and late 15-
day subsequent plans.
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of
the following information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and the new
location of the child.
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the services
provided while in residence, including medical and dental
services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that remain to be
met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan recommendations,
including medical and dental follow up that is needed, have
been reviewed with the resident and with the parent and with
the responsible case manager.
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom the
resident was discharged.
(a) One of eight discharged resident files did not have the date of discharge on the
plan.
(b)(c)(d) Two of eight discharged resident files did not document a brief summary or
other documentation of the services provided while in residence, including medical
and dental services. They did not document an assessment of the resident’s needs
that remain to be met. They did not document services that will be provided by the
facility after discharge.
(e) Two of eight discharged resident files did not document that the plan was
reviewed with the required parties.
REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report, 04/15/2020 and CAP, 04/24/20 and
Interim Report, 06/10/19 and corresponding CAP, 06/24/19. The facility must
identify why the previous plans failed and how they are going to ensure
compliance.
3

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility does not fall under MISEP reporting requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is not contracted with the Department; therefore,
contractual requirements were not assessed.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 123
The facility is advised to ensure the date of school enrollment is clearly documented
to verify the five days allowed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R 127
The facility is advised to review and ensure that youth sleeping hours do not exceed
10 hours of locked time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted no acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
There were no special investigations during this period. There was a special
investigation, 2020C0207015, from the last review period that was cited for
noncompliance with R 159(1) due to not following their restraint policy in one incident.
The CAP was due at the time of the last inspection and not assessed for compliance.
Upon review this period, the CAP was dated 04/22/20 and all items were completed.
4

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on their regular license.
June 29, 2021
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 1, 2021
